March 29, 1981: Fiction
THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen
thousand years of South African history.
BRAIN, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A young physician copes with a
conspiracy of medical researchers who steal young women's brains to create an
artificial intelligence.
CENTURY, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $13.95.) Saga of an Italian-
American family.
MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about
the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure.
THE COMPANY OF WOMEN, by Mary Gordon. (Random House, $12.95.) One
modern young woman's experience with the manners and mores of Roman
Catholicism.
ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has
made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that
engulfs his life.
THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in
Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942.
COME POUR THE WINE, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $12.95.) A
woman's long journey to self-discovery.
THE DELTA DECISION, by Wilbur Smith. (Doubleday, $12.95.) A plot to unite
international terrorist groups into one global organization.
THE AVIATOR, by Ernest K. Gann. (Arbor House, $10.95.) Romance and
adventure in the early days of the U.S. airmail service.
FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Eight year old Charlie can look
at anything and turn it into flames.
RAGE OF ANGELS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $12.95.) An idealistic young
woman lawyer triumphs over two vengeful men.
CONGO, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $10.95.) Three intrepid Americans search
for lost diamonds in the jungles of modern Africa.
UNFINISHED TALES, by J.R.R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.) Hitherto
unpublished fragments of writing about Middle-earth.
THE COLLECTED STORIES OF EUDORA WELTY. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$17.50.) Five decades of storytelling by a Southern writer who is a magnificent
March 29, 1981
Non-Fiction
COSMOS, by Carl Sagan. (Random House, $19.95.) Thirteen billion years of the
universe's evolution explained by the NASA medal-winning space scientist.
NEVER-SAY-DIET BOOK, by Richard Simmons. (Warner, $14.95.) Regimen for
exercise, diet and life style.
WILLIAM E. DONOGHUE'S COMPLETE MONEY MARKET GUIDE, by William E.
Donoghue with Thomas Tilling. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) ''How to profit from
inflation and fluctuating interest rates.''
NICE GIRLS DO, by Irene Kassorla. (Stratford Press, $9.95.) ''How women may
solve their own sexual problems.''
BEST EVIDENCE, by David S. Lifton. (Macmillan, $16.95.) An account of the
author's effort to prove that J.F.K.'s death was part of a plot by high-level
Government conspirators.
THE LAST MAFIOSO, by Ovid Demaris. (Times Books, $15.) The story of Jimmy
Fratianno, professional hit man who turned Government witness.
ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT THE IRS, 1981 Edition, by Paul N. Strassels
and Robert Wool. (Random House, $11.95.) A taxpayer's guide.
BETTY CROCKER'S INTERNATIONAL COOKBOOK. (Random House, $13.95.)
A completely new collection of recipes under a long-established name.
NOTHING DOWN, by Robert G. Allen. (Simon & Schuster, $11.95.) How to buy
real estate with little or no cash.
THE SKY'S THE LIMIT, by Wayne Dyer. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) Prescription
for ''achieving perfection of body and mind.''
YOU CAN NEGOTIATE ANYTHING, by Herb Cohen. (Lyle Stuart, $12.) ''How to
get an edge on life.''
CRISIS INVESTING, by Douglas R. Casey. (Stratford Press, $12.50.)
''Opportunities for investing in the coming Great Depression.''
CRAIG CLAIBORNE'S GOURMET DIET, by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey.
(Times Books, $10.95.) Recipes for eating well, losing weight and maintaining
good health.
PAPER MONEY, by Adam Smith. (Summit, $13.95.) An economist throws light on
that mysterious thing, money.
MONEY DYNAMICS FOR THE 1980s, by Venita VanCaspel. (Reston Publishing
Co., $15.) A money management guide for individuals.
